warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury or possible death, wear safety glasses with side shields whenever using compressed air for cleaning purposes. Limit the air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi). See "Safety Information."

step1.para: Pressure testing the cylinder head will reveal cracks in ports or sleeve leakage which cannot be observed using dye penetrant. Pressure test the cylinder head as follows:

step2.para: Fasten the Cylinder Head Pressure Test Plate tool, with rubber gasket attached, to gasket side of cylinder head. Secure plate using eight (M14) bolts and four (M8) bolts. See Special Service Tools.
Install pressure test regulator and gauge assembly to cylinder head test plate.
Immerse cylinder head in water. Apply air pressure and adjust to 124 to 138 kPa (18 to 20 psi) and inspect for leaks at the following places. If any leaks are observed replace the cylinder head:

step1.para: With the valves removed from the cylinder head, clean all valve guides using a nylon brush, soap and water. Blow out any residue with filtered compressed air.
Position an inspection light at the bottom of the valve guide bores and examine the walls for burning or cracking. Replace the cylinder head as necessary.

figure.caption: Measuring the small hole gauge (valve guide ID)

step1.para: Measure each valve guide by using a 0-1 inch outside micrometer.

step2.para: Record each valve guide inner diameter so valve-to-guide running clearance may be determined.
If valve guide inner diameter exceeds specifications, replace cylinder head. See Specifications.

step1.para: Clean valve seat area using suitable solvent, prior to visual inspection.
Inspect the exhaust valve seats for burned or cracked conditions. If any of these conditions exist, replace cylinder head.
